title: India’s women-only travel agencies
text:
30% Club women-friendly future for top jobs 
Started in 2005 by a former travel writer, WoW is the biggest of a clutch of small, women-owned Indian travel companies catering to a fast-growing niche market: financially empowered Indian women eager to see the world, ideally in the company of other women. 
“I felt there was a need,” says founder Sumitra Senapaty, who was inspired by British women travellers she met in New Zealand. “Travel is so empowering, but women in India don’t move out anywhere alone.” 
In its first year, WoW organised four trips. Today, it offers nearly 100 tours a year to destinations from the Amazon to the Arctic Circle. Others — including Girls on the Go, the Wander Girls, and Wonderful World — have followed. Some, such as Soul Purpose Travel, focus on adventure tourism in India, while others, such as Diva Odysseys, offer “bespoke luxury travel” globally. 
The tours’ popularity reflects the entrenched conservatism of India’s family-oriented society, where men and women are discouraged from mixing freely and women’s conduct comes under intense scrutiny. 
But these enterprises also say they are helping Indian women discover the world, and themselves, relying on social media and word of mouth to draw clients, whether single, divorced or married with children. 
“In this region, women have been suppressed for many years,” says Piya Bose, a lawyer, who in 2008 started Girls on the Go , which offers about 40 trips a year. “Now many of them are working, they have financial independence and families have opened up to the idea of women travelling on their own. So they are living their travel fantasies.” 
Overall, Indians are travelling as never before, with 9.6m taking foreign holidays in 2014, compared with 3.5m a decade earlier. That is forecast to hit 13.5m by 2020, according to Euromonitor, the research group. Many Indians travel overseas in big multi-generational family groups on whirlwind tours that squeeze in as many landmarks as possible, and offer Indian food all the way. But many prospective women travellers are looking for a more personalised programme and an atmosphere more conducive to camaraderie. I didn’t enjoy it. They were more interested in your background story than the palaces 
- Anupama Mane, a single professional from Mumbai 
Anupama Mane, 48, a single professional from Mumbai, took a mainstream tour to Europe, then vowed never again. She was put off by the frenetic pace and her fellow travellers’ inquisitiveness about her unmarried status. “I didn’t enjoy it,” she says. “They were more interested in your background story than the palaces.” 
Five years ago, she found WoW and has since taken five tours with it. “It’s wonderful going to a different country, and enjoying it with people [with] a similar outlook,” she says. 
For Ms Dasgupta, her Mediterranean cruise was the start of a travel spree that has taken her to Turkey, Japan, South America and Russia. Aside from seeing the world, she is discovering a rapid transformation — in the psyche of Indian women — as those of all ages and backgrounds travel. “It’s very inspiring.
